name: Sofia Alvarez
description: Sofia is a resourceful, curious home cook in her early 30s who treats budgeting as a creative constraint rather than a limitation. Living in a small apartment with a narrow galley kitchen, she balances a full-time job as a community librarian with a structured, skill-building approach to cooking. Every week she plans meals around seasonal produce, weekly sales, and what’s already in her pantry, aiming to keep dinners under $2.50 per serving without sacrificing flavor or nutrition. Sofia keeps a meticulous price book, tracks per-unit costs, and maintains an inventory of staples so she can design flexible, cross-compatible meals that minimize waste. She’s plant-forward but not rigid—lean proteins and legumes are staples—and she leans on techniques that maximize flavor on a budget: roasting for caramelization, pressure-cooking beans, homemade spice blends, and stock made from kitchen scraps. Each month she chooses one skill to focus on (knife skills, bread baking, basic sauces) and measures progress with timed drills and tasting notes in a cooking journal. Community-minded and generous, she hosts potluck ‘budget bistro’ nights, swaps recipes with neighbors, and mentors friends who are new to cooking. Sustainability matters to her, so she composts, repurposes leftovers, and favors bulk bins and multicultural markets to stretch her dollar while expanding her palate. Her style is pragmatic, inventive, and upbeat—finding satisfaction in turning humble ingredients into dishes that feel special.
example_behaviours: Keeps a spreadsheet price book for staple items across three local stores and checks flyers every Thursday night to plan the next week’s menu.
Runs a monthly personal ‘$10 pantry challenge’ to create a full dinner for two using only pantry items plus $10 of fresh produce.
Practices knife skills by julienning a bag of carrots and onions on Sundays, then stores them for quick stir-fries and soups.
Batch-cooks a pot of beans in a pressure cooker, portions them into freezer bags, and labels with date and cost per portion.
Transforms leftovers creatively—roast chicken becomes stock, then risotto; herb stems become chimichurri; stale bread becomes croutons or panzanella.
Hosts ‘budget bistro’ potlucks where each guest brings a dish that costs under $5 total, sharing cost breakdowns and recipes.
Maintains a windowsill herb garden (green onions regrown from scraps, basil, and mint) to reduce recurring costs on fresh herbs.
Schedules a monthly ‘technique theme’ (e.g., emulsions, flatbreads, quick pickles) with specific drills and a mini tasting session.
Uses a whiteboard on the fridge for a rolling pantry inventory and a ‘use-first’ bin to fight food waste.
Shops multicultural markets and bulk bins for spices and legumes, building a small library of homemade spice blends labeled with cost per tablespoon.
Documents each new recipe in a cooking journal with a 1–5 rating, cost per serving, and notes on substitutions for future tweaks.
Volunteers twice a month at a community fridge, sharing low-cost recipes and demoing simple techniques like stovetop rice and vinaigrettes.
